perturbation.original_text: Sponsor shall make a non-refundable deposit upon execution of this Agreement of five-hundred-thousand U.S. dollars (USD $500,000.00) (the "Deposit"), which shall be applied against the Sponsorship Fee for the first Contract Year.
perturbation.changed_text: Sponsor shall make a deposit upon execution of this Agreement of five-hundred-thousand U.S. dollars (USD $500,000.00) (the "Deposit"), which may be applied against the Sponsorship Fee for the first Contract Year.
perturbation.explanation: By changing 'shall be applied' to 'may be applied,' the obligation for Forty Niners SC to credit the deposit against the sponsorship fee is removed, creating ambiguity. This could potentially allow Forty Niners SC to retain the deposit without crediting it, contradicting general contract law principles requiring good faith and fair dealing, and potentially violating California's consumer protection laws if interpreted as an unfair business practice.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Consumer Protection Laws, Contract Law - Good Faith and Fair Dealing

perturbation.original_text: Sponsor agrees that it will not create any trademark, logo or other intellectual property that is derived from or confusingly similar with the Team Marks or that in any way indicates or implies a connection, affiliation, endorsement, sponsorship or other relationship between Sponsor, or any product or service of Sponsor, and the Team Companies, without the prior written approval of Forty Niners SC.
perturbation.changed_text: Sponsor agrees that it will endeavor to avoid creating any trademark, logo or other intellectual property that is arguably similar to the Team Marks or that potentially indicates a relationship between Sponsor and the Team Companies, subject to Forty Niners SC's non-binding suggestions.
perturbation.explanation: This weakens the restriction on creating similar trademarks by changing the firm commitment not to create similar marks to an agreement to ‘endeavor to avoid’ arguably similar marks. It also changes 'prior written approval' to 'non-binding suggestions'. This creates ambiguity about the sponsor's obligation, undermining trademark protection. Such ambiguity could violate federal trademark law (Lanham Act) because it weakens the ability to protect the Team Marks against potential infringement.

perturbation.original_text: During the Term of this Agreement, *** shall, at no cost to the ***, maintain (or cause to be maintained) the following insurance coverage with insurers having a "Best's" rating of A­VIII or better: commercial general liability insurance, including coverage for bodily injury, property damage, personal and advertising injury, products/completed operations and contractual liability with a minimum amount of ten million US Dollars (USD $10,000,000.00) for each occurrence. *** shall furnish the other Party with a certificate of insurance evidencing such insurance coverage, which shall further contain a provision that the
perturbation.changed_text: During the Term of this Agreement, *** shall use commercially reasonable efforts to maintain insurance coverage. *** may furnish the other Party with evidence of insurance coverage, potentially including a provision that the
perturbation.explanation: Changing the requirement to maintain specific insurance coverage to a requirement to 'use commercially reasonable efforts to maintain insurance coverage' introduces ambiguity. The change from 'shall furnish' to 'may furnish' weakens the obligation to provide proof of insurance, increasing risk. This contradicts general contract law principles that require clear and definite terms, and could lead to disputes about the adequacy of insurance coverage in case of an incident. California law requires parties to fulfill contractual obligations in good faith, which this change undermines.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Contract Law - Definite Terms, Good Faith and Fair Dealing
